result_equations.equation: \psi(x,t) = A_1\sin(k_1 x - \omega_1 t + \phi_1) + A_2\sin(k_2 x - \omega_2 t + \phi_2)

explanation: Wave interference occurs when two or more waves overlap in space and time. The superposition principle states that the total wave function is the sum of individual wave functions. This phenomenon produces constructive and destructive interference patterns depending on the phase relationship between waves.

derivation.description: Wave interference is derived from the linearity of the wave equation. When multiple waves exist in the same region, the superposition principle states that the total disturbance is simply the algebraic sum of individual disturbances.

code: x = [x_min + i * (x_max - x_min) / (n_points - 1) for i in range(n_points)]
wave1 = [A1 * math.sin(k1 * x_val - omega1 * t + phi1) for x_val in x]
wave2 = [A2 * math.sin(k2 * x_val - omega2 * t + phi2) for x_val in x]
total_constructive = [w1 + w2 for w1, w2 in zip(wave1, wave2)]
max_amplitude_constructive = max(abs(amp) for amp in total_constructive)
wave2_destructive = [A2 * math.sin(k2 * x_val - omega2 * t + phi2_destructive) for x_val in x]
total_destructive = [w1 + w2 for w1, w2 in zip(wave1, wave2_destructive)]
max_amplitude_destructive = max(abs(amp) for amp in total_destructive)

key_insights: Christiaan Huygens developed early wave theory and interference concepts
Thomas Young demonstrated interference with his double-slit experiment
Augustin-Jean Fresnel advanced mathematical theory of wave interference
The principle became crucial for understanding quantum wave-particle duality
